journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Adaptive backstepping control for a hypersonic vehicle with uncertain parameters and actuator faults

article-meta.aff: 1College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Virginia, USA

author-notes.corresp: Bin Jiang, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, 29 YuDao Street, Nanjing 210016, People’s Republic of China. Email: binjiang@nuaa.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: For a hypersonic vehicle with redundant elevators, an adaptive backstepping fault-tolerant control scheme is designed for its longitudinal motion model. In the backstepping design, the dynamic surface control strategy is adopted to eliminate the explosion of complexity in calculating the derivatives of virtual control inputs by introducing two first-order filters. An appropriate controller structure is proposed and the matching conditions are derived for adaptive fault compensation for the vehicle with redundant elevators subject to uncertain actuator faults. The adaptation laws are designed to update parameter estimates to implement the adaptive controller. The closed-loop stability under the proposed adaptive actuator fault compensation scheme is analyzed. Both analytical and simulation results are given to verify the effectiveness of the design and demonstrate the desired performance for altitude and velocity control.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a promising low-cost high-speed space vehicle to launch small satellites and achieve fast global response, hypersonic vehicles have attracted increasing commercial and military interest. However, a vast amount of research still needs to be done before such hypersonic vehicles can undertake commercial or military tasks. Hypersonic vehicles bring many challenges to control technologies due to their peculiar structure and flight conditions. There exist strong interactions between the airframe and engine dynamics and the lightweight body materials cause some vibration coupled into the rigid-body states. In addition, many parameters inherently depend on the states of the vehicle, increasing the complexity of the system dynamics and bringing uncertainties. The complex interactions between the propulsion system, aerodynamics, and structural dynamics for the longitudinal model of an air-breathing hypersonic vehicle are analyzed by Bolender and Doman.1 These characteristics of hypersonic vehicles make them a significant challenge for modeling and control.

There have been some encouraging results on controlling the longitudinal dynamics of hypersonic vehicles in recent years. Groves et al.2 designed a reference command tracking controller for the linearized longitudinal dynamics of a hypersonic vehicle using a linear-quadratic regulator (LQR) design with integral augmentation. By neglecting certain weaker couplings and resorting to dynamic extension at the input side, Parker et al.3 obtained a simplified nominal model with full vector relative degree with respect to the regulated output and applied the standard dynamic inversion technique to the simplified model for tracking control. With altitude and velocity as two outputs, the longitudinal model can be viewed as an overactuated system. Sigthorsson et al.4 considered how to utilize the control redundancy to optimize system performance in the steady state. Various techniques have been applied to the longitudinal model of hypersonic vehicles to deal with parametric uncertainties or bounded uncertainties and unmodeled system dynamics, such as the sliding model controller and observer design5–7 and the
L
1
adaptive controller.8

As a high-speed advanced space vehicle, hypersonic vehicles’ safety and reliability are critical for their potential commercial and military applications. Although the control approaches mentioned above can handle some system variations and uncertainties, their designs do not specifically consider possible system faults such as actuator and sensor faults. Therefore, their ability to deal with system faults and ensure desired stability and performance is limited. As an effective way to improve system safety and reliability, fault diagnosis (FD) and fault-tolerant control (FTC) have attracted more and more research interest and gained fruitful results. There are a few results on the FD and FTC designs for hypersonic vehicles. Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy models have been constructed to represent the nonlinear altitude dynamics9,10 and longitudinal dynamics,11 and the actuator faults were considered and modeled. Fuzzy observer-based FD and FTC control schemes were designed to detect faults and ensure the closed-loop stability at the same time. Li et al.12 presented a multi-objective fault-tolerant output tracking control scheme for a flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicle. Tang et al.13 proposed an adaptive actuator fault compensation scheme for parametric-strict-feedback systems using both adaptive control and backstepping control techniques. The proposed method can ensure the closed-loop signal boundedness and the asymptotic output tracking under parameter and actuator faults, making it an attractive candidate for the FTC design of hypersonic vehicles. However, this method requires repetitive differentiations of system nonlinearities, which are difficult to calculate for plants with highly sophisticated nonlinearities such as hypersonic vehicles. Yip and Hedrick14 proposed an adaptive dynamic surface algorithm for adaptive backstepping control of complex nonlinear uncertain systems. In that algorithm, a group of first-order low-pass filters is introduced to allow the adaptive backstepping control to be implemented without differentiating any model nonlinearities.

The current paper presents the design of an adaptive control scheme for hypersonic vehicles with unknown parameters and uncertain actuator faults based on a combination of adaptive backstepping control and dynamic surface control techniques. The advantage of the proposed control scheme is that the developed adaptive controller can effectively deal with parameter uncertainties and compensate the malfunction of the faulty actuator so that the closed-loop stability can be guaranteed and the desired tracking performance can be maintained. In the simulation studies, the proposed adaptive fault compensation scheme is applied to a hypersonic vehicle longitudinal model for its trimmed cruise conditions of 110,000ft and Mach 15, and its performances subject to a step change in altitude of 200ft and change in velocity of 100ft/s are evaluated. Simulation results demonstrate that the designed adaptive dynamic surface backstepping control scheme can ensure the boundedness of all closed-loop signals and achieve the desired tracking performance.

sec.title: Adaptive backstepping control design
sec.p: In this section, the longitudinal model of the generic hypersonic vehicle is written into a parametric-strict-feedback form and an adaptive backstepping control scheme is developed, which ensures the closed-loop boundedness and the asymptotic output tracking in the presence of parameter uncertainties and unknown actuator faults.

sec.title: Simulation
sec.p:
To verify the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive dynamic surface backstepping control approach for hypersonic vehicles, we applied the proposed method to the vehicle in its cruise model with the initial conditions:
h = 110 , 000
ft
,
V = 15 , 060
ft
/ s
,
[ γ ,
θ
p
, q ]
= [ 0 rad , 0 . 01 rad , 0
rad
/ s ]
. The control objective is to make the height and velocity of the vehicle track the desired altitude and velocity commands when unknown parameters and actuator faults exist.
Two simulations are set up in this section.

V
in Figures 2 and 3. From Figure 4, it can be observed that the adaptive law can adjust the output of the non-faulty elevator adaptively to compensate the effects of the failed elevator and make the output achieve the desired performance again after some transient process. At the same time, the velocity
V
is maintained around 15,060 ft/s and the change of the velocity due to the parameter errors and elevator fault is within the range
15 , 059 ,
15 , 060
ft / s
, which makes Assumption 2 reasonable.

Figures 7 to 10 present the trajectories of the velocity and altitude, the elevator angle, and the throttle, respectively. The velocity
V
can closely track the desired velocity 15,060ft/s despite the elevator fault and the altitude is kept around 110,000 ft simultaneously.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the current paper we investigate an adaptive control scheme for the longitudinal model of the hypersonic vehicle in the presence of parameter and actuator fault uncertainties. An augmented two-piece elevator is used as two actuators which provide the control redundancy needed by adaptive fault compensation. Under reasonable assumptions, the altitude control and velocity control are designed separately. The velocity controller is designed using the conventional dynamic inversion control technique. For the altitude tracking control, the desired altitude command is transferred into the desired flight-path command. Then the longitudinal model is formatted into a parametric-strict-feedback form so that the adaptive backstepping technique can be applied to make the flight-path angle track the desired value. To eliminate the problem of explosion of complexity coming from the partial differentiation of the plant nonlinearities in the backstepping design, we introduce two first-order low-pass filters to allow the developed algorithm to be implemented without differentiating any plant nonlinearities. The uncertain actuator fault is parameterized so that the adaptive controller can be designed based on the estimates of the actuator fault. The closed-loop longitudinal dynamics under the proposed adaptive dynamic surface backstepping control scheme is proved to be uniformly ultimately bounded. Simulation results show that the proposed adaptive control scheme ensures the closed-loop stability and desired tracking performance in the presence of uncertain parameters and actuator faults.
